Article Title: Login protocol for WA, Telegram, other apps set to change
Article Text:
Representative Image

The WhatsApp Scam That Gives Hackers Your Phone!

NEW DELHI: In just under three months, you will not be able to maintain your desktop/computer login on communication apps such as WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal and Snapchat for more than six hours at a stretch. You will have to re-login using the QR code provided by the app provider. Also, if you try to log into your communication apps on smartphones without the SIM card on which you first downloaded the app, it will not connect.This follows new orders issued by govt that say that communication apps should not allow connections on smartphones where the SIM card on which the user was originally identified is missing. The move is being taken to counter cyber fraud. Companies have to comply or face penalties. "Failure to comply with these directions shall attract action under the Telecommunications Act, 2023 , the Telecom Cyber Security Rules, 2024 (as amended), and other applicable laws," govt said.The department of telecom said the current set-up was being misused by cyber fraudsters. "... it has come to the notice of central govt that some of the app-based communication services that are utilizing mobile number for identification of its customers/users or for provisioning or delivery of services, allows users to consume their services without availability of the underlying Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) within the device in which app-based communication services is running," the department of telecom said, adding that the feature was posing a challenge to telecom cyber security "as it is being misused from outside the country to commit cyber-frauds".DoT said it had become necessary to issue the directions to prevent the misuse of telecommunication identifiers and to safeguard the integrity and security of the telecom ecosystem.DoT issued the orders on Nov 21. "From 90 days of issue of these instructions, ensure that the app-based communication services are continuously linked to the SIM card (associated with mobile number used for identification of customers/users or for provisioning or delivery of services) installed in the device, making it impossible to use the app without that specific, active SIM," it said.On the web service on computers, it said, "From 90 days of issue of these instructions, ensure the web service instance of the mobile app, if provided, shall be logged out periodically (not later than 6 hours) and allow the facility to the user to re-link the device using QR code."It asked the companies to submit compliance reports within 120 days from the issue of the directions.
Article Summary: You will have to re-login using the QR code provided by the app provider. If you try to log into your communication apps on smartphones without the SIM card on which you first downloaded the app, it will not connect. The move is being taken to counter cyber fraud. Companies have to comply or face penalties.

Article Title: Mark Cuban to Perplexity, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Microsoft: You are overspending on AI, only one you will ...
Article Text:
Overspending and the AI Bubble





What Is Artificial Intelligence? Explained Simply With Real-Life Examples

Take lessons from the dot-com era









Billionaire investor and Shark Tank judge Mark Cuban has now issued a warning to leading artificial intelligence companies including Perplexity, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Microsoft and Meta. Cuban has argued that all these companies are overspending in the race to build the world‚Äôs most powerful AI model. As reported by Business Insider, speaking in the Pioneers of AI podcast, Cuban compared today‚Äôs AI arms race to the search engine boom of 1990s. The search engine boom ultimately ended with Google dominating the market and leaving all the rivals behind.‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got five, six, whatever it is, companies that are trying to create the ultimate foundational model that we all depend on,‚Äù Cuban said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs almost like in the ‚Äô90s when all the search engines were competing pre-Google‚Ä¶ Now, we know with search engines it‚Äôs Google, and then there‚Äôs Bing, as, like, 1 or 2% and DuckDuckGo has got a half a percent. So it‚Äôs effectively a winner-take-all.‚ÄùLike many other world leaders and analysts, Cuban has also cautioned that the massive investments done on AI could ultimately lead to the creation of a bubble. ‚ÄúThey may be overspending,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúAnd if they overspend or get too caught up, the bubble is in the competition between all those models because that could pop just like that with any new technology.‚ÄùAlong with this, he also raised concerns about the infrastructure costs behind AI, majorly the massive and expensive data centers which are being built to power large models. ‚ÄúI just can‚Äôt imagine over a 10-year period that we aren‚Äôt going to improve the technology enough that if you overspend on today‚Äôs technology, it just doesn‚Äôt feel right to me,‚Äù Cuban added.Cuban also emphasised that the disruption AI will not come from incremental improvements but from something ‚Äúincredible‚Äù that no one sees coming. ‚ÄúSomebody‚Äôs going to come up with some incredible shit, right? If I knew what it was, I‚Äôd do it,‚Äù he said, suggesting that the current race may be blindsided by a breakthrough outside the existing competition.Cuban said he recognizes the same mix of hype, excitement, and overspending now playing out in AI. ‚ÄúThey anticipate for at least another decade spending every penny they have,‚Äù he said of the major model developers. ‚ÄúI mean, if that‚Äôs not ripe for disruption to come up with better ways, I don‚Äôt know what is.‚Äù
Article Summary: Billionaire investor and Shark Tank judge Mark Cuban has issued a warning to leading artificial intelligence companies including Perplexity, OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Microsoft and Meta. Article Title: How to clear Gmail storage and keep your inbox running smoothly
Article Text:
Why does Gmail storage fill up faster than expected

How to clear Gmail storage quickly and effectively

Empty the Trash and Spam folders

Delete large emails and attachments

Remove newsletters and old promotional emails

Use the Google One Storage Manager to clear space across all services

Habits that prevent Gmail from filling up again

When you might need more storage

Also read|





Running out of storage on Gmail can be stressful, especially when important emails start bouncing back or the service becomes slow. Many people do not realise how quickly storage fills up across connected Google services like Drive and Photos. Since Gmail shares its storage with the rest of the Google account, everything from attachments to uploaded files contributes to the limit. When the warning appears that storage is almost full, it can feel overwhelming. Fortunately, there are simple and practical steps that help clear space without spending money on upgrades. With a little organisation and a few smart habits, it is possible to reduce clutter and regain smooth performance in your inbox.Google provides an official Storage Manager that helps users see exactly what is taking up space across Gmail, Drive and Photos. The tool highlights large files, old emails with attachments and unnecessary items that can be deleted safely. It is the most reliable method since it works directly with data stored in the cloud rather than guessing what to remove.Gmail storage includes emails, sent items, drafts, attachments and everything stored in Google Drive and Google Photos. Even if the inbox does not appear full, large attachments or uploaded videos may be using most of the space.Promotional emails, newsletters, archived messages and old backups also count towards the total. Deleted items continue to occupy storage until they are permanently removed from Trash, which is why simply deleting emails does not always free space. When storage reaches its limit, Gmail stops receiving new mail and certain functions may not work correctly. Understanding what contributes to the total makes it easier to clean up effectively.When emails are deleted, they move to Trash and stay there for up to 30 days. They still count towards storage until the Trash is emptied. The same applies to the Spam folder. By opening each folder and selecting the option to permanently delete all items, users often free up space instantly.Attachments are usually the biggest contributors to storage use. Gmail provides search filters that help locate bulky messages. Searching for terms like has: attachment larger:10M displays emails with attachments larger than 10 megabytes. Once these are found, they can be deleted in bulk or downloaded elsewhere before deletion.Promotional categories often accumulate thousands of unread messages because newsletters, offers and automated campaigns pile up quickly without being noticed. These can be selected and removed together to clear storage space and improve inbox performance. If many emails come from the same sender, unsubscribing prevents future build-up and keeps incoming mail manageable by stopping unnecessary notifications permanently. Over time, this simple clean-up habit reduces digital clutter, improves focus and makes it easier to find important conversations without endless scrolling or searching.The Google One Storage Manager scans all the services linked to a Google account and lists files that consume the most space. It separates storage usage into sections such as large emails, deleted items, large files in Drive and backed-up photos or videos. This approach ensures that nothing is missed, especially when files outside Gmail are the primary cause of reduced space. Through a single interface, large items can be reviewed and removed safely without confusion.Regular maintenance avoids repeat storage problems. Clearing old attachments, emptying Trash frequently and reviewing large items every few months helps maintain free space. Avoiding the habit of emailing large files repeatedly can also help. Instead of attaching high-resolution photos and videos directly to emails, it is better to share links from Drive or alternative storage platforms. This allows senders to delete the original attachments without losing access to the files. Unsubscribing from mass mailing lists also helps maintain a clean inbox.For users dealing with intensive file exchange, such as designers, editors, photographers and students, the default free storage may not be enough. In such cases, upgrading to a paid Google One plan is a practical solution. Using two Google accounts is also an option, allowing heavier tasks to be separated from regular daily email.Clearing Gmail storage does not need to be complicated. With a structured approach and support from the official Google tools, anyone can free space quickly and enjoy uninterrupted messaging. Reducing unnecessary files keeps email performance fast, improves organisation and helps stay focused without clutter.A few minutes of clean up can restore full functionality and avoid the frustration of running out of space at the wrong moment. The best approach combines one-time clean-up with regular habits that prevent build-up in the future, keeping Gmail efficient and reliable.
Article Summary: Gmail storage can fill up quickly, especially when important emails start bouncing back or the service becomes slow. Google provides an official Storage Manager that helps users see exactly what is taking up space across Gmail, Drive and Photos. The tool highlights large files, old emails with attachments and unnecessary items that can be deleted safely. Unsubscribing from mass mailing lists also helps maintain a clean inbox.

Article Title: Microsoft: Tech Layoffs: Layoffs at Microsoft, Meta, Google, Twitter: What is 'career cushioning' and why it's important
Article Text:
As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning'.

Q: What is career cushioning?

Q: Why is career cushioning important?

Q: How can I start career cushioning?

Q: What are some examples of career cushioning?

Q: Is career cushioning only for people in certain industries?

Q: How often should I review and update my career cushioning efforts?

Q: How do I know if my career cushioning efforts are working?

Q: How much time should I be dedicating to career cushioning?

NEW DELHI: Microsoft Corp is reportedly planning to cut thousands of jobs, with some roles expected to be eliminated in the human resources and engineering divisions, according to media reports on Tuesday.This move follows similar job cuts announced by other tech companies, such as Amazon, Meta Platforms , Twitter, Google , Salesforce and a host of other corporations.These job cuts are being attributed to slowing demand and a worsening global economic outlook. The move by Microsoft indicates that the tech sector may continue to shed jobs in the coming months.As job cuts continue to rise in tech and various other industries, some employees are choosing to proactively seek out new job opportunities while still employed. This strategy, referred to as " career cushioning ". Here is all you need to know on 'career cushioning'A: Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable and resilient to job loss or industry changes. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.A: Career cushioning can help provide a sense of security and confidence in uncertain job markets and can also open up new opportunities for career advancement. It can also help you be better prepared if you do lose your job, making it easier to find new employment.A: There are several ways to begin career cushioning, such as:Building a diverse skill set through continuing education or volunteer workNetworking with professionals in your industry and other industriesBuilding a personal brand through social media and professional online presenceSaving money for unexpected career changes or job loss.A: Some examples of career cushioning include:-A software developer taking on freelance web design projects to gain experience in user interface design.-A marketing professional starting a blog to gain experience in content creation.-A sales representative taking on additional responsibilities in product development to gain experience in product management.A: No, career cushioning is applicable for people in any industry. It's about being proactive in preparing for potential changes in your career, regardless of the industry you're in.A: It's a good idea to review your career cushioning efforts regularly, perhaps once or twice a year. This will allow you to assess your progress and make any necessary adjustments to your plans. Additionally, keeping an eye on the job market and industry trends can help you anticipate and prepare for any potential changes in your field.A: You can gauge the effectiveness of your career cushioning efforts by monitoring your progress in gaining new skills and experiences, as well as the feedback you receive from your professional network and potential employers. Additionally, you may find that you are better able to adapt to changes in your industry, or that you have more opportunities available to you.A: The amount of time you should dedicate to career cushioning will depend on your individual goals and circumstances, however it's important to balance the time you spend career cushioning with your other responsibilities. A good rule of thumb is to spend some time each week or month working on career cushioning activities, but not to the point that it negatively impacts other areas of your life.
Article Summary: As job cuts continue to rise in various industries, some employees are going for 'career cushioning' Career cushioning refers to the practice of building a diverse set of skills and experiences in order to make oneself more marketable. This can include gaining experience in multiple areas of a field, developing a side hustle or passion project, or building a professional network.

Article Title: Ekman, who linked facial expressions to emotions, dies at 91
Article Text: Paul Ekman, a psychologist who linked thousands of facial expressions to the emotions they often subconsciously conveyed, and who used his research to advise FBI interrogators and screeners for the Transportation Security Administration as well as Hollywood animators, died Nov 17 at his home in San Francisco. He was 91.Ekman sought to add scientific exactitude to the human impulse to interpret how others feel through their facial expressions. He recorded 18 types of smiles, for example, distinguishing between a forced smile and a spontaneous one; a genuine smile, he discovered, crinkles the orbicularis oculi muscle - that is, it creates crow's feet around the eyes.Sometimes described as the world's most famous face reader, Ekman was influential in reshaping the way facial expressions were understood - as the product of evolution rather than environment - and his findings crossed over to popular culture.As a young researcher in the late 1960s, Ekman changed the scientific consensus on facial expressions. In the postwar era, the conventional wisdom of eminent anthropologists like Margaret Mead was that human facial expressions were learned and that they varied across cultures. Ekman believed otherwise. He showed photographs of people making faces expressing 30 different emotions - including anger, joy and fear - to subjects in the United States, Japan and South America.Across cultures, the study's participants linked the expressions they were shown with the same emotions.He then travelled to Papua New Guinea with a colleague, Wallace V Friesen, and showed the same pictures to some 300 Indigenous people who had no exposure to modern media and could not have learned to interpret faces that way. These subjects also connected the expressions to the same emotions."There is a pan-cultural element in facial expressions of emotion," Ekman wrote in a paper in 1970 on returning to the United States.
Article Summary: Paul Ekman, a psychologist who linked thousands of facial expressions to the emotions they often subconsciously conveyed, died Nov 17 at his home in San Francisco. Ekman was influential in reshaping the way facial expressions were understood. He recorded 18 types of smiles, for example, distinguishing between a forced smile and a spontaneous one.

Article Title: Inside the deal-making power of the F-35: A weapon, a network, a strategic lock-in
Article Text:
Israel Or Saudi, Who Has F-35 Edge? Mid-East Air Power Balance Decoded; Game-Changer Or Paper Tiger?

The Israel - Saudi Arabia dynamics





Let's dive deeper into what this beast really is :-





What defines a

fifth-generation fighter jet

? A full breakdown

.

How Washington uses fighter jets as diplomacy and leverage

Why the Saudi F-35 deal raises concerns: The China-Pakistan angle

The global map of fifth-generation fighter jets: Who has what

The United States‚Äô F-35 ‚Äî dominant in number & deployment

China‚Äôs J-20 ‚Äî the leading non-Western competitor

Russia‚Äôs Su-57 ‚Äî operational, but limited in scale & integration

How the US retains control through software, sanctions and upgrade restrictions

Why the US limits updates and weapons access even for its allies

Why the F-35 stands beyond Russian fifth-gen capability

Inside the satellite-driven combat network that makes the F-35 nearly invisible





NEW DELHI: The "Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II" is not just another fighter jet ‚Äî it is a geopolitical instrument, a technological ecosystem and the most widely exported fifth-generation aircraft ever produced. No other defence platform in the modern era has reshaped alliances, altered regional balances of power, or influenced international diplomacy the way the F-35 has. From Europe to West Asia, from the Indo-Pacific to Nato‚Äôs forward edge, the aircraft has become a tool through which Washington strengthens partnerships, discourages adversaries, builds influence and enforces compliance.The F-35 represents more than stealth ‚Äî it represents networked warfare, real-time intelligence fusion and precision strike capability that allows pilots to ‚Äúsee first, fire first and disappear.‚Äù A US analyst once summarised the aircraft in one sentence: The F-35 is what happens when a jet becomes a computer that kills.Its strategic dominance is the reason states compete to buy it ‚Äî and also why Washington tightly controls who receives it, at what configuration, when upgrades are released, and what internal code becomes accessible. The F-35 is both a fighter and a foreign-policy lever.As the United States tries to rebalance the Middle East through fighter jet diplomacy and trade, a proposed sale of its most advanced combat aircraft, the F-35, to Saudi Arabia has put Israel firmly at the centre of the debate.The potential deal, discussed during Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman‚Äôs visit to the White House and his talks with US President Donald Trump, envisages Riyadh joining the exclusive club of F-35 operators. But officials and reports say the Saudi jets, if the sale goes through, will be delivered in a less advanced configuration than those flown by Israel, in line with Washington‚Äôs long-standing commitment to preserve Israel‚Äôs qualitative military edge in the region.According to Reuters, US officials have indicated that the F-35s planned for Saudi Arabia will lack some of the superior features installed on Israel‚Äôs fleet, including advanced weapons systems and electronic warfare equipment. Israel, which has been operating the F-35 for roughly eight years, enjoys unique permissions to modify its aircraft, integrating its own weapons and adding radar-jamming and other upgrades without seeking fresh US approval. Still, the Israeli Air Force has opposed the proposed Saudi sale, warning in a position paper to political leaders that it could erode Israel‚Äôs air superiority in the region, The Times of Israel reported. Defence experts also note that even if Saudi Arabia gets the jets, it is unlikely to receive the AIM-260 Joint Advanced Tactical Missile, the next-generation air-to-air weapon being developed for fifth-generation platforms, as Douglas Birkey of the Mitchell Institute for Aerospace Studies has pointed out.A fifth-generation fighter jet is not simply a more modern aircraft ‚Äî it is a leap in how air warfare is fought, sensed, processed and won. Fourth-generation jets like the F-16, Su-30 or Mirage 2000 are machines of speed, thrust and manoeuvre, designed for visual-range engagements with radar as their primary sensor. Fifth-generation fighters are not built merely to fight ‚Äî they are built to detect, decide and destroy without ever being seen.In military terms, a fifth-generation fighter is defined by a convergence of technologies rather than a single capability. The first is stealth. These aircraft are engineered to minimise radar cross-section through angled geometry, radar-absorbent composites, internal weapons bays that eliminate external drag signatures, and infrared suppression to reduce heat signature. Unlike earlier fighters, which radiate powerfully when scanning for threats, fifth-generation jets can enter heavily defended airspace without announcing themselves.The second defining feature is sensor fusion. A modern fifth-generation aircraft does not feed a pilot separate streams of radar, infrared, targeting pod and electronic surveillance data. Instead, onboard computers merge all sensor inputs ‚Äî from the aircraft itself and from external assets such as AWACS, satellites or friendly fighters ‚Äî into one single tactical picture. Pilots no longer interpret dials; they see the entire battlespace as if viewed from above.The third layer is network-centric warfare. Fifth-generation fighters are not lone hunters. They are nodes in a digital combat mesh, sharing encrypted data silently through low-probability-intercept links. An enemy aircraft detected by one jet can be targeted by another. A missile launched by a ground battery can be guided by the data uplink of an aircraft hundreds of kilometres away. This ability to fight as a distributed swarm rather than as isolated aircraft fundamentally reshapes air power.Advanced avionics and electronic warfare complete the definition. A fifth-generation jet can jam enemy radars, spoof missile seekers, absorb electromagnetic signals for tracking, and identify threats passively without using its own radar. And unlike legacy platforms, which improve only with major hardware refits, fifth-generation jets evolve through software. Each system upgrade can expand detection range, add weapons integration, enhance stealth performance, and reconfigure threat libraries without redesigning the airframe.True fifth-generation capability, therefore, is not just stealth or thrust ‚Äî it is stealth + fusion + networking + EW dominance + software-driven evolution. Only a few nations have achieved it at scale. The United States leads with the F-22 and F-35, China fields the J-20, and Russia‚Äôs Su-57 is still maturing. Others, from Japan and South Korea to India and Europe, are now racing toward sixth-generation development.For United States, selling a fighter jet ‚Äî especially one as tightly controlled and technologically dense as the F-35 ‚Äî is never just an arms deal. It is foreign policy with wings. Fighter exports form the backbone of long-term military partnerships, binding nations to American logistics chains, software ecosystems, training infrastructure and, by extension, strategic alignment. Unlike traditional defence sales that end at delivery, fifth-generation platforms create decades-long dependence through updates, maintenance and weapons integration cycles. In practice, a country purchasing an American fighter is not just buying an aircraft ‚Äî it is entering a relationship.Washington has mastered this form of influence. Nations that operate US platforms rely on American training academies, spare-parts pipelines, engine overhaul depots, weapons testing facilities and encrypted mission-data updates. Every missile added, every software patch authorised, every radar mode unlocked passes through Washington. This system of controlled access means jets double as diplomatic leverage ‚Äî a partner aligned with US interests receives faster upgrades, deeper integration, and next-generation weapons; one that defies US strategic preferences risks delays, sanctions or removal from programmes entirely.Turkey stands as a pivotal example. Once a full partner in the F-35 programme, it was expelled after purchasing Russia‚Äôs S-400 missile system, losing aircraft access, industrial participation and billions in future revenue. The message was clear: ownership is conditional, and alignment is monitored continuously. In West Asia, the dynamic is even sharper. While Israel receives the most advanced F-35 variant with unrestricted modification rights, Saudi Arabia and the UAE face conditional pathways shaped by politics, security guarantees and trust evaluations. The aircraft has become a reward in geopolitical negotiation ‚Äî allocated not just by purchase capacity, but by reliability as an ally.Washington also uses fighter jet access to shape regional balance. When Russia grows more assertive in Europe, Nato states receive accelerated F-35 deliveries. When China expands its footprint in the Pacific, Japan, South Korea and Australia acquire larger fleets. Where deterrence is needed, jets are not merely sold ‚Äî they are stationed, forward-deployed and network-integrated. Air power becomes a diplomatic signal: a squadron represents intent; a fleet represents alignment.The possible sale of American F-35 fighter jets to Saudi Arabia has triggered concern within US defence circles, mainly over fears that sensitive technology could slip into the hands of China or Pakistan.A New York Times report, citing a Defense Intelligence Agency brief, outlined concerns that China could eventually access stealth-signature, electronic warfare and radar-absorption modelling if Saudi Arabia imported F-35s into an environment where Chinese contractors provide network infrastructure or defence systems integration. Fifth-generation technology is not just metal and avionics ‚Äî it is algorithms, mission-data files, sensor-fusion logic, heat-signature shaping and software-defined radar behaviour. Modern aircraft intelligence can be compromised by observing emissions, not stealing hardware.The risk is amplified by how the F-35 works. Its stealth coating chemistry, radar-cross-section shaping and EW system profiles are jealously guarded secrets. Even partial exposure ‚Äî radar testing from different angles, heat-signature mapping during take-off, or electromagnetic sniffing during exercises ‚Äî could help adversaries develop counter-stealth solutions. A single compromised maintenance facility, a breached digital-link terminal or a shared runway environment can generate exploitable telemetry.Pakistan emerges as a secondary risk vector. Though Saudi Arabia would not directly transfer Western equipment to Islamabad, support personnel, training officers, or data exposure through joint exercises could indirectly benefit Pakistan‚Äôs China-aligned aviation programmes, including development of the J-20 and future stealth derivatives. Washington‚Äôs caution reflects precedent: Pakistan received F-16s under strict conditions, and even those platforms faced upgrade restrictions over decade-long concerns of technology diversion to China.This is why, even if Riyadh eventually receives the aircraft, officials quoted by Reuters and defence analysts note the jets would almost certainly be a restricted configuration ‚Äî without Israel-level electronic warfare autonomy, without independent modification rights, and likely without access to the AIM-260 JATM, the most sensitive next-generation air-combat missile. The architecture would be export-sanitised because leakage is difficult to reverse.US officials say the sale is still under review, and any final agreement will require a detailed security assessment. For now, Washington is weighing two priorities ‚Äî strengthening ties with Saudi Arabia, and ensuring the F-35‚Äôs sensitive technology does not reach rival powers.Fifth-generation fighters remain the rarest and most strategically valuable aircraft in the world ‚Äî and today, only a handful of nations operate them at scale. At the centre of this landscape is the American F-35, the only fifth-gen platform deployed across multiple continents, services and alliances.The United States leads the field, operating all three variants ‚Äî Air Force (F-35A), Marine Corps STOVL (F-35B) and Navy carrier-based (F-35C). The jet is now the backbone of Western air power and has been adopted or ordered across Europe, including by the United Kingdom, Italy, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands and Finland. In the Indo-Pacific, Japan, South Korea and Australia have emerged as major F-35 operators, a deployment pattern closely aligned with Washington‚Äôs broader strategy to deter Chinese expansion.Israel became the first operator in West Asia and remains the only regional user to have deployed the F-35 in real combat missions, benefiting from exceptional access, early delivery and custom integration rights.Outside the US-led ecosystem, fifth-generation efforts are smaller and far more limited. China‚Äôs J-20 is the most advanced non-Western platform currently in service, designed primarily for long-range interception and air-superiority missions, with an eye on US surveillance aircraft and refuelling tankers in the Pacific. Beijing is also developing a second stealth jet ‚Äî the FC-31/J-35 ‚Äî expected to serve aboard future carrier groups.Russia fields the Su-57, but in small numbers, constrained by sanctions, funding pressures and production inefficiencies. While technologically capable in manoeuvrability and close-combat performance, the fleet remains too small to shift global balance in the near term.A few nations are developing future systems ‚Äî Japan‚Äôs F-X, the UK-Italy-Japan Tempest programme, Europe‚Äôs FCAS, and India‚Äôs AMCA ‚Äî yet none have reached operational maturity.As of now, the global fifth-generation landscape is essentially a three-pole arena:Until the next generation arrives, the F-35 remains the benchmark ‚Äî and the only stealth fighter shaping alliances across the world.One of the least visible but most powerful aspects of the F-35 programme is software control. Modern aircraft are software-defined machines. Their flight characteristics, radar modes, electronic warfare responses, weapons employment envelopes and threat libraries are all governed by lines of code. In previous generations, once an aircraft was exported, the buyer had considerable freedom to alter and integrate systems. The F-16 could be rewired and retrofitted domestically, and several countries built their own versions or added indigenous weapons.The F-35 is different. Core mission software, electronic warfare libraries, and threat-identification files are not transferred outright; they are licensed and regularly updated via US-approved channels. This means that Washington retains decisive influence over how far and how fast an F-35 operator can expand its capabilities. Upgrades can be slowed, withheld or tailored. Certain weapons or radar modes can be restricted. In extreme cases, the flow of support and spare parts can be cut altogether.Turkey‚Äôs experience offers a case study. After Ankara took delivery of Russia‚Äôs S-400 air defence system, the US government removed Turkey from the F-35 consortium, halted planned deliveries and shifted production work away from Turkish firms. In effect, the programme was used not only as a supply contract but as an instrument of sanction. For potential buyers such as Saudi Arabia or the UAE, the message is clear: access to the F-35 comes with expectations about broader strategic alignment, and divergence carries costs.Even among close partners, Washington carefully calibrates the level of capability it provides through the F-35. This is partly driven by the legal requirement to maintain Israel‚Äôs qualitative military edge in West Asia, and partly by a broader desire to prevent sensitive technology from falling into hostile hands or being reverse-engineered.In practice, this means that not all F-35 operators receive the same radar modes, electronic warfare options or weapons integration at the same time. Highly sensitive systems such as next-generation air-to-air missiles, advanced stand-off weapons and cutting-edge jamming suites may be offered only to a small subset of trusted allies, or delayed until Washington is confident that the regional balance will not be destabilised.There is also a structural interest in maintaining dependence. If every country had identical capabilities and full control over their F-35 software environment, the leverage that comes from upgrade control would diminish. For the United States, the ability to say ‚Äúnot yet‚Äù or ‚Äúnot this particular weapon‚Äù is part of how it shapes the behaviour of even close partners. This sometimes generates friction: air forces that see themselves as front-line contributors to coalition operations may resent being held back from the latest configurations. But from Washington‚Äôs perspective, the risks of over-sharing are high, particularly in a world where cyber espionage and covert technical cooperation blur the lines of trust.Comparisons between the F-35 and Russia‚Äôs Su-57 are often framed in symbolic terms: two rival fifth-generation fighters, representing two competing geopolitical blocs. Yet in practical terms, the two aircraft inhabit different worlds.The F-35 is more numerous by an order of magnitude. Global F-35 deliveries have crossed the four-figure mark and are still rising, with long-term projections of more than 3,000 aircraft over the life of the programme. The Su-57, by contrast, is present only in small numbers, with production hampered by sanctions, industrial constraints and budgetary pressures. This matters because air power, especially in prolonged conflicts, depends not just on the quality of individual aircraft but on the ability to sustain and replace losses.Stealth and networking also separate the two platforms. The Su-57 incorporates stealth features, but open-source assessments suggest that its radar cross-section reduction is inferior to Western designs, particularly from the rear and at certain frequencies. Coating durability, nozzle shaping and panel fit all contribute. The F-35, drawing on decades of US work on the F-117, B-2 and F-22, is widely assessed to have a lower signature and more mature low-observable maintenance regime.More fundamentally, the F-35 is integrated into a wider Western network of satellites, ground stations, AWACS and datalinked assets. The Su-57 operates primarily within Russia‚Äôs own air defence and command infrastructure, which does not have the same global reach or the same level of coalition interoperability. In a beyond-visual-range engagement, the ability of a fighter to draw on offboard sensors can be as important as its onboard performance. On that metric, the F-35‚Äôs ecosystem gives it a significant advantage.If stealth is the body of the F-35‚Äôs advantage, the satellite-networked combat system that surrounds it is the mind. The jet is deeply integrated into secure satellite communication networks that relay encrypted tactical information from across a theatre and beyond. These links allow the F-35 to receive target coordinates and threat data from sources hundreds or even thousands of kilometres away, including space-based sensors, maritime platforms and airborne early warning aircraft.Because it can rely on this stream of external information, the F-35 does not need to use its own radar aggressively to build a picture of the battlespace. Its passive sensors ‚Äî infrared cameras, electronic support measures and distributed aperture systems ‚Äî detect emissions from enemy radars, missiles and aircraft. The mission computer fuses these inputs with offboard data, presenting the pilot with a coherent, real-time picture. In a radar-saturated environment such as the Taiwan Strait or Eastern Europe, this allows the F-35 to remain electronically quiet while still operating with full awareness.This networked approach changes how air campaigns are planned. A formation of F-35s can act as forward sensors for other aircraft or missile systems, passing back targeting data without ever exposing themselves. They can launch weapons cued by remote sources or guide munitions fired by other platforms. Rather than thinking of each jet as a discrete combatant, planners increasingly view them as nodes in a mesh network.For countries that buy the F-35, entry into this network is as significant as acquisition of the aircraft itself. Key components of hallmark on gold jewellery



Gold, silver hallmarking : Gold and silver jewllery have long been treasured for their beauty and value. However, ensuring their purity and authenticity is important, especially in a market prone to fraudulent practices. This is where the hallmarking scheme comes into play. Here‚Äôs what you need to know about hallmarking charges and its procedures:Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver.It serves as a guarantee of their purity or fineness. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820, according to an ET report.Hallmarking charges are applied per article, regardless of its weight. For gold articles, the charge is Rs 45 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 200 for a consignment. Similarly, for silver articles, the charge is Rs 35 per article, with a minimum charge of Rs 150 for a consignment. It's important to note that additional taxes and levies may apply.A consignment refers to a collection of articles with the same fineness, from which a sample is drawn and assayed for compliance. Different lots may exist within a consignment.Anyone can have their hallmarked jewellery tested for purity at an A&H centre by paying a testing fee of Rs. 200 (for testing using the fire assay method as per IS 1418). These centres must be recognized by the BIS. The list of recognized A&H centres is available on the BIS website under the hallmarking section.The primary objective of hallmarking is to safeguard consumers from counterfeit products. To achieve this, the Indian government made hallmarking mandatory for gold jewellery from June 16, 2021. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification ( HUID ) number.If you bought gold jewellery on or before June 30, 2021, it may have old hallmarking signs. These signs include the purity/fineness mark and the BIS emblem, along with two additional indications: the jeweller's identification number and the assay centre's mark/number.However, starting July 1, 2021, these two indications were replaced with a unique alphanumeric HUID code. The hallmark remains valid for the lifetime of the jewellery, and consumers can sell old jewellery, whether hallmarked or un-hallmarked, to jewellers.The HUID, or hallmark Unique Identification number, is a key component of hallmarking in gold jewellery. It's a unique six-digit alphanumeric code assigned to each hallmarked item, allowing for traceability. Customers can verify the HUID number using the 'Verify HUID' feature in the BIS Care App.Since the introduction of the HUID on July 1, 2021, the hallmark on gold jewellery consists of three marks: the BIS logo, the purity of the article in caratage and fineness, and a unique six-digit alphanumeric HUID number.
Article Summary: Hallmarking is the process of accurately determining and officially recording the proportionate content of precious metals in articles, such as gold and silver. In India, hallmarking is governed by stringent standards outlined in IS 15820. Since April 1, 2023, jewellers are prohibited from selling any gold jewellery without a 6-digit Hallmark Unique Identification number.

Article Title: Meet Charlie Javice: Woman who scammed JP Morgan for $175M ‚Äî but the bank is paying her $142M legal bills
Article Text:
How a startup deal turned into a massive fraud

The controversial expenses

Why JPMorgan cannot simply stop paying

Charlie Javice‚Äôs story sounds almost too bizarre to be real: a young fintech founder who tricked JPMorgan into buying her startup for $175 million, ended up convicted of fraud, and is now serving a prison sentence, yet the same company she scammed is still paying more than $142 million for her legal bills, including questionable expenses like luxury hotel upgrades and ‚Äúcellulite butter. ‚ÄùJavice founded Frank, a platform advertised as helping students navigate financial aid. When JPMorgan considered acquiring the startup in 2021, she reportedly presented the bank with millions of supposed student user accounts. Prosecutors later revealed that these numbers had been fabricated, with Javice allegedly hiring a data scientist to generate fake profiles to inflate Frank‚Äôs value.JPMorgan completed the acquisition believing Frank had more than four million users, only to discover after the deal that the platform had a tiny fraction of that. The bank alerted authorities, and by 2023 Javice was arrested on federal fraud charges.In March 2025, Javice was convicted of multiple fraud counts and sentenced to more than seven years in prison. But here‚Äôs where the story takes an unusual twist: despite defrauding the bank, she is still allowed to bill JPMorgan for her legal defence because of an indemnification clause included in the acquisition agreement.This contractual protection, which is common in startup buyouts, requires JPMorgan to cover certain legal costs for former executives of Frank.As a result, the bank has already paid over $142 million in defence expenses for Javice and her former colleague Olivier Amar.The clause itself is a standard feature in mergers, designed to protect executives from being financially ruined by lawsuits connected to their time at the company. In normal situations, it is meant to ensure fairness and prevent frivolous legal targeting after an acquisition. But in this case, it has trapped JPMorgan in a bizarre obligation: they must keep funding the defence of someone who defrauded them.Had the bank conducted even a simple, early-stage verification of Frank‚Äôs user data‚Äîsuch as requesting direct access to the platform‚Äôs actual customer records or running a basic audit‚Äîthis entire dispute could have been avoided. Instead, delayed due diligence and overconfidence in the startup‚Äôs claims set the stage for a costly legal mess that continues years after the fraud was uncovered.JPMorgan‚Äôs frustration has grown as the legal bills have ballooned. The bank claims the expenses submitted include personal items such as cellulite butter, first-class travel upgrades, and hotel luxuries. Article Title: Government tells WhatsApp, Telegram and others to link services to SIM cards: What it means for users
Article Text:
What it means for multi-device users and travellers







The Union government has issued new directives requiring messaging apps to enforce SIM card verification and automatically log out web-based sessions every six hours. This means that users will be barred from accessing their services if they do not have a physical SIM card originally used to register for the app present in their device. The directive by the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) will affect major platforms including WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Arattai, Snapchat, Sharechat and others, and are aimed at combating cyber fraud.According to the notice, these communication apps must ensure within 90 days that their services remain ‚Äúcontinuously‚Äù linked to the SIM card used during registration. They must block access if the SIM is not present in the device ‚Äì a technical requirement known as SIM binding. Additionally, web-based versions of these apps, such as WhatsApp Web, must log out users periodically, with sessions not exceeding six hours.‚ÄúIt has come to the notice of Central Government that some of the app based communication services that are utilizing mobile number for identification of its customers... allow users to consume their services without availability of the underlying SIM within the device...posing challenge to telecom cyber security as it is being misused from outside the country to commit cyber-frauds,‚Äù DoT stated in its notice.The government is invoking powers from the Telecommunication Cybersecurity Amendment Rules, 2025, notified in October, which introduced the concept of Telecommunication Identifier User Entity (TIUE) under telecom regulations.WhatsApp has more than 500 million users in India, and the new regulations may hinder daily use. For example, some people use multiple devices, like phone and tablets, or two phones but link them to use one account on both the devices. They may experience disruptions due to the mandate of SIM binding.Further, people who use WhatsApp on their PCs to lessen their screen time on phone and restrict themselves to communication on messaging apps are likely to face disruption during work hours.‚ÄúPresently, the binding process between a subscriber's app-based communication services and their mobile SIM card occurs only once during the initial installation and verification phase, after which the application continues to function independently on the device even if the SIM card is later removed, replaced or deactivated,‚Äù COAI previously stated.
Article Summary: New regulations require messaging apps to enforce SIM card verification. WhatsApp, Telegram, Signal, Arattai, Snapchat, Sharechat and others will have to comply. They must block access if the SIM is not present in the device ‚Äì a technical requirement known as SIM binding.
